description:
Aspergillus oryzae RIB40 is a strain of the filamentous fungus Aspergillus oryzae, which is widely used in the production of traditional Japanese fermented foods such as sake, soy sauce, and miso. This strain, RIB40, has been extensively studied and is a key industrial microorganism.

Aspergillus oryzae RIB40 is a saprophytic fungus, meaning it obtains its nutrients from decomposing organic matter. It is a thermophilic organism, capable of growing at relatively high temperatures, and is known for its ability to produce a variety of enzymes, including amylases, proteases, and lipases, which allow it to break down complex carbohydrates, proteins, and lipids, respectively.

The genome of Aspergillus oryzae RIB40 has been sequenced, providing insights into the genetic and metabolic capabilities of this strain. It has a large genome size, with approximately 37 million base pairs, and is known to possess a rich repertoire of genes involved in the production of secondary metabolites, which can contribute to the unique flavors and aromas of the fermented foods it is used to produce.

Aspergillus oryzae RIB40 is considered a safe and well-characterized organism, and its use in food production has a long history, making it a valuable asset in the food and biotechnology industries.
